label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, May 27, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, commenting on a folio of pictures she had sent him of various friends and family members and delivering news of his brother, Armant.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, commenting on a folio of pictures she had sent him of various friends and family members and delivering news of his brother, Armant.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
May 27, 1943
Dear Gertie,
The pictures of Bo arrived this morning and I was amazed 
by her resemblance to Sarah Jane. They really look amazingly alike.
Is'nt it curious how family resemblances run in families. I can
understand children looking like their parents but when Aunts and
Uncles come into the picutre I am always a little bit puzzled.
The little Phipps boy looks just like his father and
I am certain he is pink and white and will look like a pig under
a gate by the time he is nine. They were all very cute sitting there
by the side of thepool, and reminded me of a couple of puppy dogs.
There is one picture of Lester sitting in a garden with Tom Evans.
Is that your garden[,] because it is enormous and looks very attractive.
I like the wall and do hope that there are lots of flowers and nice
things to lend it charm. The pictures of the Field Marshall are
wonderful. He belongs at Medway, has that worn lookXabout the face,
and the general thiness of the southerner. In fact if you had not
written that it was Dill I ould have thought it was John Gadsden['s]
brother. Tony was w nderful. Certainly no one would ever accuse
him of being a throughbred. The general impression I gathered from the 
pictures of Medway that I have seen[,] was a run down at the heel
place whose troubles were mirrored on the faces of those there. Walter
who was standing behind Reggie had the most terrfied expression on his
face as if he expected Tony to drop in his tracks, something I must
admit I was a little firghtened of also when I looked at those legs
and lowered head.
Little Ann looked so attractive in her picture. She has
really turned into a most attrXactive looking girl, and I should
think you would feel very happy that you had given her such a chance
in life. It probably xxxxx has made her entire view point different[,]
and where she would have lived in her little group in New Orleans
thinking it was the only one in the city she now realizes that it
takes a great many people to make the world, and that many of them
are more attractive than the ones she will find in the deep south.
Armant is going to San Pedro which is ver[y]near Los Angles.
One of our Yeoman tells me that it is a most attractive place with
a climate that is unbeatable and swimming that keeps you in the water
whenever you have the opportunity. It may fascinate him so that
he will want to live there the rest of his life away from the heat
and bad climate of New Orleans, so that after all his [not] comming out here
was for the best. We were terribly sorry that he could not make it,
especially when it was all so close, but all hope [illegible] at the end.
Other Officers were sent here and therefor we had no grounds to ask
for him.
Goodbye darling, all my love. Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 2]
